edges.description: Electrical power flows from the grid to distributed sensors, enabling continuous environmental monitoring across the urban fabric.
Actuators draw power to translate digital commands into physical motion—opening valves, switching signals, adjusting facades.
Mobile robots consume significant metabolic load for locomotion and computation. Fleet scaling directly stresses grid capacity.
Aerial drones require charging infrastructure distributed across the city, creating new demands on the electrical distribution network.
Edge compute nodes draw continuous power for low-latency inference, concentrating thermal and electrical loads at network periphery.
Electric autonomous vehicles require charging infrastructure that reshapes grid demand curves and distribution topology.
Solar-powered sensors can operate off-grid, extending monitoring into areas without electrical infrastructure.
Market crashes, foreclosure waves, and speculative bubbles persist in institutional memory, forcing the Market Agent to discount aggressive growth scenarios.
Past disasters—floods, fires, storms—shape the Climate Agent's risk calibration, ensuring hazard models reflect lived experience.
Displacement events, redlining legacies, and broken promises create community trauma that the Community Agent must weight in feasibility assessments.
High social friction signals that regulatory approval will face organized opposition, forcing the Policy Agent to recommend mitigation measures.
The Community Agent directly consumes friction data to advocate for stakeholder interests in council deliberations.
Past rent curves, absorption rates, and investment returns create the baseline expectations against which the Market Agent evaluates new opportunities.
High fear dampens investor appetite and lengthens approval timelines; high preparation signals adaptive capacity that de-risks investment.
Community preparedness levels inform the Climate Agent's assessment of resilience—whether populations can adapt to projected hazards.
Displacement risk is the Community Agent's primary concern, forcing trade-offs between growth and protection into explicit council debate.
Regulatory voids create uncertainty that the Policy Agent must flag—where law is silent, risk is unquantifiable.
Raw sensor telemetry flows into knowledge graphs where it becomes structured 'City Facts'—semantic entities with typed relationships.
Environmental readings trigger dynamic constraint updates—air quality data may activate temporary use restrictions.
Mobile robots continuously update spatial knowledge: obstacle locations, traversability conditions, and occupancy patterns.
Aerial surveillance generates high-resolution imagery that feeds building footprint extraction and change detection algorithms.
AV fleets generate massive traffic flow data, revealing actual mobility patterns that may diverge from planning assumptions.
Parcel ownership records connect physical assets to human stakeholders, enabling equity impact analysis.
Parcel characteristics—size, frontage, access—feed market potential calculations for development feasibility.
Agent deliberation outputs flow to governance structures as decision support, informing policy adjustments.
Zoning codes bind to parcels, defining the envelope of permissible development—the primary shape-maker of urban form.
FAR limits cap buildable area, directly determining economic yield and shaping the massing of every structure.
Setback requirements carve the building footprint from the parcel boundary, creating the negative space of streets and yards.
Height limits define the vertical envelope, capping the extrusion of footprints into habitable volume.
Approved entitlements modify base zoning constraints, unlocking additional development capacity on specific parcels.
Environmental review requirements constrain development timelines and may mandate mitigations that alter project feasibility.
Geological conditions constrain foundation design, limiting tower heights and deep basement feasibility on specific parcels.
High water tables preclude below-grade construction without expensive dewatering, constraining parking and basement space.
Flood zone designations trigger insurance requirements and elevation mandates that fundamentally alter development economics.
Rights-of-way define legal corridors for robot movement; sidewalk widths and curb conditions constrain fleet operations.
Street geometry, lane widths, and intersection configurations constrain AV operational envelopes and route planning.
Regulatory voids around robot operations leave contested spaces ungoverned, creating friction without clear resolution mechanisms.
Contested regimes instruct the Policy Agent to prioritize procedural legitimacy, stakeholder engagement, and litigation risk avoidance.
Directed regimes instruct the Policy Agent to prioritize efficiency, rapid permitting, and strategic alignment with state objectives.
Under contested governance, the Community Agent's voice carries greater weight in council deliberations.
Directed regimes may privilege Market Agent recommendations when growth targets align with state development priorities.
Policy-as-Code translates legislative intent into executable constraint objects, automating compliance verification.
Digital zoning codes derive from policy-as-code implementations, making regulatory text machine-interpretable.
Jurisdictional boundaries determine which infrastructure capacity constraints the Infrastructure Agent must consider.
International climate commitments and sustainability frameworks shape the Climate Agent's optimization targets.
Stakeholder mobilization—voting, lobbying, litigation—shapes contested governance outcomes and policy priorities.
The Market Agent advocates for entitlement modifications that would improve project feasibility.
Robot presence in neighborhoods creates lived experience that shapes stakeholder attitudes toward synthetic actors.
Actual flood events validate or refute the Climate Agent's risk models, forcing recalibration of probability assessments.
Observed temperature trends, precipitation patterns, and extreme events validate climate projections used in feasibility analysis.
Transaction records and development outcomes validate the Market Agent's feasibility predictions.
Permit approvals and denials validate the Policy Agent's compliance assessments and timeline predictions.
Actual utility loads and service failures validate the Infrastructure Agent's capacity models.
Real-time environmental readings provide ground truth that validates or contradicts model predictions.
Traffic counters, utility meters, and infrastructure monitors provide validation data for capacity models.
Identified regulatory gaps signal to jurisdictions where law is failing to address emerging conditions.
Agent deliberation outcomes provide feedback on whether contested governance processes achieve legitimate decisions.
Ridership data and service performance validate the Infrastructure Agent's transit accessibility assumptions.
The Infrastructure Agent provides path planning intelligence to mobile robots, enabling navigation through complex urban environments.
The Community Agent provides ethical constraints to robots: where to slow down, which areas to avoid, how to minimize disruption.
The Policy Agent translates regulatory requirements into operational constraints for robotic fleets.
Drone flight paths are planned with infrastructure capacity awareness—avoiding restricted airspace, coordinating with traffic management.
FAA regulations, local ordinances, and privacy rules flow through the Policy Agent to constrain drone operations.
AV routing optimizes for system-level traffic flow based on Infrastructure Agent's capacity models.
The Climate Agent influences AV behavior during extreme weather events—rerouting for flood avoidance, reducing speeds in heat waves.
Building actuators respond to energy market signals, adjusting HVAC and lighting based on price optimization logic.
Agents exchange data during council deliberations—the Market Agent's feasibility numbers inform the Community Agent's displacement analysis.
Climate risk assessments directly impact financial feasibility—the Climate Agent's outputs feed Market Agent's risk adjustments.
Regulatory timelines and approval probabilities inform infrastructure investment decisions across the agent council.
Stakeholder concerns identified by the Community Agent shape the Policy Agent's assessment of political feasibility.
Infrastructure capacity limits affect climate adaptation options—the two agents must coordinate on resilience strategies.
Flood zone boundaries directly inform zoning overlays that restrict development in hazardous areas.
Community resistance to adaptation measures (managed retreat, elevation requirements) shapes climate response feasibility.
Market demand data directly informs the Market Agent's absorption assumptions and pricing models.
Existing entitlements validate development potential—approved rights are bankable assets for feasibility analysis.
Regulatory gaps around synthetic labor create uncertainty that the Infrastructure Agent must factor into deployment scenarios.
Past negative encounters with robots create stakeholder memory that affects acceptance of expanded synthetic labor.
Material availability constrains the Infrastructure Agent's recommendations—can't build with resources that don't exist.
Smart actuators report infrastructure status—valve positions, pump rates, load levels—maintaining the digital twin of physical systems.

E.name: Energy
E.description: Physical power required to run the city. Flows from grid to robots/sensors.

M.name: Memory
M.description: The systemic brake. Carries weight of past shocks forcing agents to reject risky scenarios.

D.name: Data
D.description: Raw observations flowing up to be translated into City Facts.

C.name: Constraint
C.description: The shape maker. Transmits rules that physically mold buildings and parcels.

I.name: Intent
I.description: Represents motivation. Tells agents what to optimize for.

V.name: Validation
V.description: The reality check. Compares agent predictions against actual sensor readings.

R.name: Reasoning
R.description: Brain-to-body connection. Robots subscribe to access high-level ethical and navigational logic.

structural-L0.name: Metabolic Cluster
structural-L0.description: The base of the graph, grounding all other connections in planetary reality.

structural-L1.name: Identity Cluster
structural-L1.description: The central spine to which all regulatory and physical data snaps.

structural-L2.name: Nervous System Cluster
structural-L2.description: The bridge connecting physical ground to digital logic.

structural-L3.name: Logic Cluster
structural-L3.description: A dense web of rules hovering above the physical city.

structural-L4.name: Agency Cluster
structural-L4.description: The brain of the graph, radiating intent edges downward.

structural-L5.name: Memory Cluster
structural-L5.description: The conscience, wrapping around agents to constrain them.

structural-L6.name: Governance Cluster
structural-L6.description: The canopy—highest level of abstraction and authority.

risk-resilience.name: Risk & Resilience
risk-resilience.description: Nodes that co-occur when describing safety, insurance, and climate adaptation.

capital-value.name: Capital & Value
capital-value.description: Nodes that define the financial viability of the city.

synthetic-labor.name: Synthetic Labor
synthetic-labor.description: Nodes describing conflict and integration of new robotic workers.

metabolic-flow.name: Metabolic Flow
metabolic-flow.description: Nodes mapping the physical consumption of resources.
